{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3147231,"name":"CJ Hill","username":"CJ_Hill","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cj_hill/{size}/142363_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-17T02:58:34.795Z","cooked":"

Has anyone been able to use the encoder that comes with the armabot turret (armabot pdf, sensor details) with the SPARK MAX as an absolute encoder?
The pinouts look the same as the Talon SRX, so it looks like the 10-pin cable should just go in to the SPARK MAX w/o changing anything. We have the encoder configured with the jumper to enable digital output, and are setting up the controller and encoder like this:

turret_controller = rev.CANSparkMax(9, rev.CANSparkMax.MotorType.kBrushless) absolute_encoder = turret_controller.getAbsoluteEncoder(encoderType=rev.SparkMaxAbsoluteEncoder.Type.kDutyCycle)

We’re getting some data from reading the absolute encoder but it resets to zero every time we re-power the robot, so somehow we’re either just getting fooled by noise or there is some other default reset going on and (maybe) we need to permanently burn something in to the controller to stop that from happening.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-02-17T04:22:03.633Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":270,"reads":142,"readers_count":141,"score":1378.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":427128,"topic_slug":"spark-max-and-armabot-absolute-encoder","display_username":"CJ Hill","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://cdn.shopify.com/s/files/1/1518/8108/files/Armabot_A0067-0100_Absolute_Encoder_Interface_Control_Document.PDF","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":13},{"url":"https://ams.com/as5145b","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"AS5145B - 12-bit rotary position sensor + 12-bit pre-programmed incremental mode - ams | ams","clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32094,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2429 mentor"},"post_url":"/t/spark-max-and-armabot-absolute-encoder/427128/1","custom_user_title":"2429 mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3147254,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-17T03:19:27.508Z","cooked":"

What signal is your sensor returning for its absolute position? PWM? Looks like it supports quadrature encoding as well, so just wanted to check.

What pin(s) do you have that signal wired to?

The SparkMax dataport is indeed the same, but the internal function of the controller differs if I remember correctly (my team hasn’t used a TalonSRX in a couple years). Specifically, REV uses the quadrature encoder pins for the NEO’s internal hall-effect sensor when in brushless mode, so those pins cannot be used. When in Absolute Encoder mode, it uses pin 6 for the PWM signal., which is an unused pin for the TalonSRX. So you have to ensure you’re wired properly.

Thanks, for expediency we just switched to the analog output of the absolute encoder. I’d much rather use the digital, because the analog is noisy on the order of a degree. We have to take a good fraction of a second to calibrate on robot startup.
I was hoping the 10-pin designed for the talon was compatible with the 10-pin on the SparkMax, but looks like not. Thank you for pointing that out. I’ll see if I can get a simple crossover cable made (hopefully it only needs one jumper.) It’ll have to wait until after the week 2 competition, however. I’ll post the diagram that works.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-02-20T14:49:22.513Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":92,"readers_count":91,"score":33.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":427128,"topic_slug":"spark-max-and-armabot-absolute-encoder","display_username":"CJ Hill","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":9105,"username":"Fletch1373","name":"Fletch","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32094,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2429 mentor"},"post_url":"/t/spark-max-and-armabot-absolute-encoder/427128/3","custom_user_title":"2429 mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3149047,"name":"Lexeo","username":"Lexeo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lexeo/{size}/160041_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-20T15:04:07.803Z","cooked":"
CJ_Hill:

because the analog is noisy on the order of a degree

We had this issue too on a different application. It appears their is a problem with the ADC on many of our new Spark Maxs (I think we found 4-5 Sparks with this issue - all brand new). You can do a quick check by using the REV hardware client and reading the analog input. We found that the voltage input gets up to ~3.8V rather than the maximum 3.3V. The data is also pretty noisy. When we use a “good” Spark MAX, the data is quite good.

I haven’t had a chance to reach out to Rev support on the problem yet (plan to this week) but it’s something I would check.

Thanks, we had one already on the way! However, I’ve had good results in the past taking the standard 1.27mm pitch 10 pin cable and just swapping one line - since the powers are all the same on the two encoder ports, I may only have to jumper one wire, and that ends up much cleaner than soldering multiple connections to the alternate encoder port.

Our analog was noisy coming straight out of the encoder’s analog output into the roborio. We didn’t experience this aspect.

Shouldnt have to solder anything. It has the 10-pin port on top and and internally remaps that pin for you. Youd have to check the pinout to be certain, but I think it should just work

I’m not quite following. That rev part looks like it is for the JVST cable coming out of of the REV thru-bore encoder and then mapping it to the 10-pin input on the sparkmax.

I don’t have that setup. I have a 10-pin cable from the Armabot absolute encoder ostensibly meant for the TalonSRX input. So not matter what I don’t have a plug and play option with the REV absolute encoder adapter. Am I wrong?
